content.question:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="H P R with a positive one charge aqueous, which is yellow, plus O H with a negative one charge aqueous, is in equilibrium with P R aqueous, which is red, plus H 2 O liquid" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtable columnalign="left" rowalign="baseline" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtext>HPR</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mtext>PR</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.5em"></mspace><mi>y</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>w</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="8.0em"></mspace><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></math>

The acidified form of phenol red, <math alttext="H P R with a positive one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>HPR</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , is yellow with a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="435 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>435</mn><mtext> nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. It reacts with hydroxide ions according to the equation above, producing water and phenol red (<math alttext="P R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), which has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="555 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>555</mn><mtext> nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

a) Write the <math alttext="K sub e q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> expression for the equilibrium reaction above.

The absorption spectra of an equilibrium mixture of <math alttext="P R, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PR</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>and <math alttext="H P R with a positive one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>HPR</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, collected at two different temperatures, are shown in the following diagram.

frqParts.text:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="H P R with a positive one charge aqueous, which is yellow, plus O H with a negative one charge aqueous, is in equilibrium with P R aqueous, which is red, plus H 2 O liquid" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtable columnalign="left" rowalign="baseline" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtext>HPR</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mtext>PR</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.5em"></mspace><mi>y</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>l</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>w</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="8.0em"></mspace><mi>r</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>d</mi></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></math>

The acidified form of phenol red, <math alttext="H P R with a positive one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>HPR</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , is yellow with a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="435 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>435</mn><mtext> nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. It reacts with hydroxide ions according to the equation above, producing water and phenol red (<math alttext="P R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), which has a strong absorption peak at a wavelength of <math alttext="555 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>555</mn><mtext> nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

a) Write the <math alttext="K sub e q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> expression for the equilibrium reaction above.

The absorption spectra of an equilibrium mixture of <math alttext="P R, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PR</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>and <math alttext="H P R with a positive one charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>HPR</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, collected at two different temperatures, are shown in the following diagram.

(b) Which peak, the one at <math alttext="365 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>365</mn><mtext> nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> or the one at <math alttext="435 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>435 nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, results from the absorption of photons with the greater energy? Justify your answer.
(c) Based on the diagram above, is the forward reaction endothermic or exothermic? Justify your answer in terms of Le Châtelier’s principle.

A calibration plot of the absorbance at <math alttext="555 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>555 nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> versus the concentration of <math alttext="P R, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>P</mtext><mtext>R</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></math> is shown in the following graph.

(d) Based on the best-fit line in the graph, what is the approximate absorbance value for a solution in which <math alttext="the molar concentration of P R equals, 1.5 times 10 to the negative 5 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>PR</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1.5</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

(e) A student measures the absorbance of a solution of <math alttext="P R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of unknown concentration in order to determine the <math alttext="molar concentration of P R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>PR</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in the solution using the calibration plot above. The cuvette is rinsed with water, then with a small amount of the solution, which is discarded. Finally, the cuvette is filled with the mixture for analysis. Explain why rinsing the cuvette with a small amount of solution is important to ensure an accurate absorbance measurement.

Over time, <math alttext="P R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> converts to a colorless molecule in the presence of <math alttext="O C l with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions. To study the rate of the reaction, the student recorded the absorbance of the <math alttext="P R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution at <math alttext="555 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>555</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in a <math alttext="2.00 molar K O C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution. The temperature and <math alttext="the molar concentration of O C l with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>[O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> remain constant throughout the reaction. The results are summarized in the table below.

Time

(<math alttext="in hours" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>h</mtext><mtext>r</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>)

Absorbance

0
 0.40

0.40
 0.32

0.80
 0.25

1.20
 0.20

1.60
 0.16

2.00
 0.13

2.40
 0.10

(f) Determine the half-life of the reaction. Include units in your answer.

(g) Explain how the absorbance and time data are consistent with a process that is first order with respect to <math alttext="P R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

A second trial is conducted at the same constant temperature, but with <math alttext="the molar concentration of O C l with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> changed to <math alttext="0.500 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.500</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The observed half-life of the reaction is longer than for the first trial when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O C l with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> was <math alttext="2.00 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(h) Explain, in term of particle collisions, why the half-life of the reaction increases when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O C l with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is changed from <math alttext="2.00 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="0.500 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.500</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(i) Is the activation energy for the reaction when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O C l with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext></mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="2.00 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, the same as, or less than the activation energy when <math alttext="the molar concentration of O C l with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext></mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="0.500 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.500</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer.

In order to prepare the original <math alttext="2.00 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of <math alttext="K O C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, a student follows a procedure with the following steps.
Step 1: Measure out <math alttext="90.6 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>90.6</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></math> of <math alttext="K O C l, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.
Step 2: Add <math alttext="1.00 liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of distilled water to a <math alttext="2.000 liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.000</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> volumetric flask.
Step 3: Add the <math alttext="K O C l, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to the flask and swirl to dissolve the <math alttext="K O C l, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.
Step 4: Add enough distilled water to bring the mixture to the line on the volumetric flask, inverting several times to mix.
(j) The chemical quantities used in the procedure do NOT produce <math alttext="2.00 molar K O C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Describe specifically how they should be changed in order to produce <math alttext="2.00 molar K O C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(k) Another student is preparing a <math alttext="2.00 molar K O C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>2.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></math> solution using the correct chemical quantities but notices that some solid remains at the bottom of the volumetric flask. Describe an action that the student should take to ensure that the remaining solid dissolves.

(l) When making the solution above, the student notices that the temperature increases when dissolving <math alttext="K O C l, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>OC</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in water. In a separate experiment, the student dissolves <math alttext="1.0 mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>mo</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="K O C l, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext><mtext>OC</mtext><mtext>l</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> in <math alttext="1000 decimal point grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1000.</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> each of two different solvents, X and Y. Assuming the enthalpy change is the same regardless of solvent, would the temperature change in solvent X be greater than, less than, or equal to the temperature change in solvent Y? Justify your answer. The specific heat capacities of solvent X and solvent Y are given in the table below

Solvent
 X
 Y

Specific Heat Capacity

​(<math alttext="in joules per gram degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>J/(g</mtext><mo>·</mo><mtext>°C)</mtext></mrow></math>)

1.8
 2.2

skill.text: 2.C: Identify experimental procedures that are aligned to a scientific question (which may include a sketch of a lab setup).
